title: Even though Shakespeare said 'A rose by any other name would smell as sweet' do people put too much importance on labels like the Communist State East Germany was officially called the 'German Democratic Republic'? - Quora

response.answer_text: One is a rather beautiful literary allusion used to highlight an important question pertaining to a human condition, and an individual’s position in the social order. The other is strongly political and heavily imposed, it also relates to the human condition, but has a much broader effect upon the social order. It is a couple of lines later in Juliet’s lovely little speech that a good idea is born regarding political claptrap, when she beseeches “Romeo doff thy name.” Social snobbery, or political ideology, it’s all about power.
A phenomenon called euphemism in political language when near all communist countries where officially named “peoples republic of” () or “democratic”. Now widely used by “conservative” populism.
